webTitle: Qantas: hundreds of passengers stranded in Dubai over New Year's

fields.bodyText: Hundreds of Qantas passengers spent New Year’s Eve stranded in Dubai after their flight to Sydney was delayed by more than 20 hours. Engineers in Dubai worked on the A380 aircraft while passengers were put up in hotels while they waited to learn when they could fly to Australia. Other flights at Dubai international airport, the world’s busiest for international travel, were delayed by fog. The UAE’s National Center of Meteorology & Seismology issued a fog warning on Saturday morning, saying visibility had dropped below 100 metres in most areas. High humidity and falling temperatures cause the fog to roll in seasonally along the coast of the Arabian Peninsula. The murk threatened to spoil a fireworks display at the Burj Khalifa, the world’s tallest at 828 metres (2,716ft), which was expected to draw hundreds of thousands of people on Saturday night. Some Qantas customers expressed their frustration at the delays on social media. “I’ve been delayed for 8 hours in Dubai airport. You sent people that you delayed yesterday off on my plane and now I’m stranded,” Mia Parkes-Talbot posted to the airline’s Facebook page from Dubai on Friday night. “I really want to go home and celebrate New Year’s Eve with family, friends and dog. Please get me home now! Please get me home before I have to spend the first moments of 2017 in an airport hotel.” Meanwhile, others searched for answers. “You’ve put us up in a lovely hotel but we have no idea what time we’ll be leaving tomorrow. What time do we set our alarms for please? Help and communication would be great. Lots of uncertainty. Thanks,” Rob Voase wrote. “Hi Qantas, what’s happening with your flights from Dubai? A friend is stranded there for days and may even miss NYE in Sydney. What’s the story?” said Steven Powell. The airline said it was keen to safely fly passengers to Sydney as soon as possible. “The engineering assessment is continuing and, once resolved, we’ll be able to provide an updated arrival time,” a Qantas spokeswoman said on Saturday. “We’re keen to get passengers on their way, but only when it’s absolutely safe to do so. We thank everyone for their patience.”

webTitle: How attempts to save BHS, and 11,000 jobs, were doomed by chaos and mistrust

fields.bodyText: On the day the BHS store in Edinburgh closed down, Lin Macmillan, a former employee, decided to visit it one last time. “It was really sad,” she said. “The staff were obviously very upset but still acted professionally.” Macmillan worked for BHS for a decade and is one of more than 20,000 pensioners who face a cut to their income after the collapse of the company. “I first realised something was wrong in March when I got a leaflet from the pension trustees about what would happen if the company went into administration. I was like, hmm – they wouldn’t do that if there wasn’t a problem.” A month later, BHS did indeed collapse into administration. This led to the closure of all 164 shops, the loss of 11,000 jobs, and left a £571m pension deficit. “I was angry and sad,” Macmillan added. “It was avoidable if Green and his family hadn’t milked the company in the way they did. Chappell was way out of his depth. He took something on that he didn’t understand. The Green family are entirely to blame. They must have been delighted to find an idiot to sell it to.” Green and Chappell – Sir Philip Green and Dominic Chappell – became two of the most vilified people in Britain after the demise of BHS. At a time when Britain was divided about its future in the European Union, it was united in anger at Green, the billionaire tycoon, and Chappell, the three-time bankrupt. According to a parliamentary report into the failure of BHS, Green and Chappell had systematically plundered the retailer before it shut. Green controlled BHS for 15 years until he sold it to Chappell’s company, Retail Acquisitions, for £1 in March 2015. During this period, the tycoon, his family and other shareholders collected more than £580m in dividends, rent and interest payments on debt. Retail Acquisitions, meanwhile, was paid at least £17m – despite having owned the chain for only 13 months before its demise. In June 2016, Green pledged before MPs that he would “sort” the problems facing the BHS pension scheme. However, as 2016 drew to a close, a rescue deal had failed to appear. The repercussions of BHS’s failure – one of the biggest corporate scandals to hit Britain in the 21st century – will continue to be felt through 2017. Although the parliamentary committee led by Labour MPs Iain Wright and Frank Field has delivered its verdict, there are other investigations still underway. The Pensions Regulator, the Insolvency Service, the Financial Reporting Council, HM Revenue & Customs and the Serious Fraud Office are all still looking into the circumstances surrounding the collapse of the 88-year-old chain. Macmillan hopes the Pensions Regulator, led by Lesley Titcomb, can force the Green family to pay money into the BHS pension scheme. “I hope she uses the power she has to force them to pay up,” she said. “They will still be fabulously wealthy anyway.” The Pensions Regulator has started legal proceedings against Green and Chappell in an attempt to force them to fill the BHS pension deficit. It is understood to be seeking £350m from Green and as much as £17m from Retail Acquisitions, which is 90% owned by Chappell. At the same time, the Insolvency Service is investigating the conduct of the former directors, the Financial Reporting Council is examining the audit of BHS’s 2014 accounts by PricewaterhouseCoopers, and the SFO is looking into possible grounds to launch a formal criminal investigation into the closure of the retailer. Green’s knighthood also remains on the line after MPs voted in favour of stripping it from him. This will ultimately be decided by honours forfeiture committee, which will make a recommendation to the prime minister and the Queen. A spokesperson for Green said he had nothing further to say on the collapse of BHS or his discussions with the Pensions Regulator. However, Chappell was unrepentant when contacted by the Observer, and insisted the blame for the BHS collapse lay with Green and the retail managers who ran the store chain from day to day. “There are three reasons why it collapsed,” he said. “Philip undertook to deal with the trade credit insurers [who ensure that retailers do not have to pay suppliers upfront for goods] and he did not do that. We needed another £30m that we had not budgeted for because we couldn’t deal with the trade credit insurers. He also undertook to deal with his moral hazard on the pension scheme, which he did not do. This screwed our finances. The third thing that crippled us was the very bad trading that the company did last Christmas, led by Darren Topp [the former chief executive]. “We have been criticised heavily for having no retail experience. We backed the management of BHS, we funded them, and we produced funds of around £80m for them to do their turnaround.” Chappell, who says his life since the collapse of the company has been “extremely difficult”, also defended the millions Retail Acquisitions took out of the BHS. “We’re not a charity,” he said. “We weren’t ever going to do this for nothing. We had significant costs pre-acquisition. We complied with every single thing that we needed to do as directors, and at no stage did we trade immorally. We did everything we possibly could to try to resolve the BHS issue and we were let down on three matters.” However, others involved with the matter have significantly different views on the conduct of Chappell and Retail Acquisitions. Evidence submitted to the parliamentary investigation into the collapse of the company describes the chaos in the final days of the high street chain. Topp and Michael Hitchcock, the two most senior retail executives at BHS in the run-up to its failure, have been severely critical of Chappell. They, and Green, dispute his version of events. “Like many others throughout this process, I think I was duped,” Hitchcock, a former financial consultant, told MPs about his interactions with Chappell. “I think the technical term is a mythomaniac. The layperson’s term is that he was a premier league liar and a Sunday pub league retailer, at best.” Topp added: “To be honest, I took it at face value that it was true [that Chappell could help turn BHS around]. Unfortunately, as time progressed, that unravelled in terms of that promise, and it became clear towards the end that rather than putting money in, he had his fingers in the till.” The key to BHS’s survival was persuading landlords to reduce their rent bills, which Topp believed would be possible once BHS was free from Green’s empire. This turned out to be true: in March 2016, landlords voted in favour of dramatically cutting the rent on 87 of BHS’s 164 shops. Unfortunately, by that point the company’s finances were unravelling and key suppliers, credit insurers and other stakeholders had lost faith in Chappell, warning Topp that BHS needed new owners in order to be successful. Topp’s faith in Chappell had started to unravel the previous June, when documents submitted to the Pensions Regulator revealed financial transactions that made him uncomfortable. As part of its investigation into the company, the regulator had served BHS with a “section 72 notice”, requiring it to disclose financial documents. These documents showed that the £10m that Retail Acquisitions had put into BHS had been borrowed, that it had taken a £7m cut from the sale of BHS’s head office, North West House on London’s Marylebone Road, and that Chappell and his personal company, Swiss Rock, had been paid £1.8m after buying the department store chain. Topp said he felt “exposed”, so had brought in Hitchcock to be his finance man. Hitchcock quickly became concerned about Retail Acquisitions, eventually changing BHS’s rules so that two directors had to sign off every expense. The movement of money out of BHS became public just weeks before landlords voted on whether to cut the company’s rent, when the Guardian revealed the existence of an £8.4m loan between BHS and Retail Acquisitions, of which roughly a third had gone to its directors, including Chappell. The anger was palpable among landlords who were being asked to take a financial hit and BHS staff who were losing their jobs. Topp says he approached Green around this time over his concerns about Chappell and what they could do. Green’s retail business, Arcadia, still ran back-office functions for BHS such as payroll, sold products in its shops, and was owed £40m by the company – making it a key creditor and partner. Green had remained in contact with Topp and Chappell since selling BHS. However, it was too late. Even though landlords agreed to reduce their rental payments, BHS needed to raise another £100m in order to survive. Chappell and his team could not raise enough from selling property and a new loan he proposed came with onerous and expensive terms, meaning it was rejected by the rest of the management team. On Monday 25 April, BHS went into administration. Officially – and controversially – it was Green who pulled the plug and brought in Duff & Phelps as administrator, which he had the power to do because of the £40m debt BHS owed to Arcadia. By this point, the relationship between the main parties had disintegrated. Topp did not trust Chappell, Chappell thought Topp was plotting behind his back with Green, and Green was hurtling into the biggest crisis of his career. Chappell tried to reach a last-minute rescue deal with Mike Ashley’s Sports Direct, but failed. Green claims that he was advised by Duff & Phelps to issue the demand that pushed BHS into administration in order to protect the salaries of its staff in the event a rescue package could not be secured. Green read a letter from Duff & Phelps to MPs that claimed HMRC had issued a seven-day winding-up notice against BHS, that lawyers acting for the board of BHS had advised the directors they were at risk of wrongful trading, and that the salaries of staff might not be paid unless the retailer was protected by an administration order. However, Chappell insists Green could have saved BHS and blames him for the company going into administration. Amid those chaotic last days of BHS and the fraught meetings, Chappell moved £1.5m out of the retailer into an unconnected entity called BHS Sweden. Topp said he initially thought this was theft and confronted Chappell, who allegedly threatened to kill him. Chappell said the money was for professional fees, but eventually paid it back. After the collapse of the company the Guardian revealed other transactions that had caused concern for BHS management. These included Chappell using £1.5m of BHS money to pay off the mortgage on his family home just as it was about to be repossessed; the sale of BHS’s warehouse to a friend of Chappell’s (with Retail Acquisitions taking a third of the proceeds); and a series of complex loans and property deals between Chappell, BHS and property company Allied Commercial Exporters, which made millions of pounds from the transactions. In the week that BHS fell into administration, Chappell was in the Bahamas. An abusive note was pinned on the wall in one of the lifts at BHS’s head office criticising Retail Acquisitions and the money they collected from the retailer. Chappell, meanwhile, sent a text message to Topp when it was confirmed that all BHS shops were to close. “Well done,” it read. “I hope you and Michael are happy that you got the out come [sic] you wanted. You fucking prick.” Duff & Phelps, the administrator to BHS, has, according to sources, filed a damning report on the conduct of Chappell and Retail Acquisitions. FRP Advisory, the liquidator, is understood to be conducting further investigations into some of the transactions under Retail Acquisitions. Green, meanwhile, claims he was misled by Chappell and blames him for the furore of the past year. Retail analysts say the lack of investment in BHS under Green and the mismanagement under Chappell pushed over the edge a business that would have been struggling anyway in the present retail market, where sales are moving from the high street to online, and department stores are under pressure. “It was a relic. It was a model that had passed its sell-by date many years ago,” Richard Hyman, an independent retail consultant, said. “It had been overtaken by discount stores such as Primark, but it was also underinvested. The mismanagement was in fact the final of a number of straws.” For the staff of BHS, however, the downfall of the business was about much more than its place on the high street: it was their livelihood. Grant Atterbury, a worker who wrote a diary for the Guardian during the last weeks of BHS, said: “There was no tearful farewell to the old building [in Tunbridge Wells] as we exited the front doors for the last time, because, having sat in the stifling heat doing nothing for the previous three hours, we were all desperate to stretch our legs and feel some fresh air on our faces. No one even looked back, as far as I recall.” Last week – as Green and his family were reported to be spending the holidays in a Miami celebrity enclave – Atterbury wrote an update on his life post-BHS, outlining his struggle to pay the rent and how he had been forced to take a loan from his mother to cover his food bills until his benefit claim is processed. Hundreds of other former BHS workers have had to apply for grants from the Fashion and Textile Children’s Trust – a 163-year-old charity once chaired by Charles Dickens – for hardship payments. Atterbury wrote: “The fact that throughout the country countless other ex-BHS employees are facing similar situations and worse fills me with anger and sadness.” Where are they now? Sir Philip Green After appearing in front of MPs and pledging to “sort” the BHS pension scheme, Green spent the summer on his new £100m yacht, Lionheart, in the Mediterranean. His only public appearance since has been an interview with ITV’s Robert Peston, when he said he was “sad and very sorry” for the collapse of the company and that it has been a “horrible” time for him and his family. The Pensions Regulator has started legal proceedings against Green and a decision whether to strip him of his knighthood will be made when official investigations have been completed. Dominic Chappell Spent much of his time since BHS collapsed juggling requests for information and interviews by regulatory bodies. He was banned from driving for six months in August. Chappell claims Retail Acquisitions is looking to do new deals, but the liquidators want to wind the company up and it faces a court hearing in January that will determine whether it survives. Darren Topp Left BHS after its shops closed in August, but is already back in retail. Topp was appointed in September as chief executive of luxury fashion and footwear chain LK Bennett. Michael Hitchcock has joined him as chief financial officer. Paul Sutton Chappell was working as Sutton’s driver when Green pulled out of a deal to sell BHS to Sutton. This paved the way for Chappell to become involved. Green scrapped the deal because a whistleblower delivered him a dossier revealing that Sutton had been convicted of fraud in France in 2002. Sutton and Chappell have since fallen out, with Sutton claiming that he could have saved BHS, while Chappell bled it dry. Sutton is now looking to revive his business career and move back to Monaco.

Chappell claims Retail Acquisitions is looking to do new deals, but the liquidators want to wind the company up and it faces a court hearing in January that will determine whether it survives.

Darren Topp Left BHS after its shops closed in August, but is already back in retail. Topp was appointed in September as chief executive of luxury fashion and footwear chain LK Bennett. Michael Hitchcock has joined him as chief financial officer.

Paul Sutton Chappell was working as Sutton’s driver when Green pulled out of a deal to sell BHS to Sutton. This paved the way for Chappell to become involved. Green scrapped the deal because a whistleblower delivered him a dossier revealing that Sutton had been convicted of fraud in France in 2002. Sutton and Chappell have since fallen out, with Sutton claiming that he could have saved BHS, while Chappell bled it dry. Sutton is now looking to revive his business career and move back to Monaco.
fields.trailText: And in the months since it collapsed, Philip Green has not fulfilled his pension pledge, and former staff are left struggling on benefits

webTitle: Sterling's slide: winners and losers in 2016

fields.bodyText: Uncertainty over the outlook for the UK economy after the Brexit vote in June has sent the pound plummeting to levels not seen since the 1980s. After the initial falls, Theresa May’s announcement that she would trigger article 50 by March and continuing talk of a hard Brexit piled more pressure on sterling. As did an emergency cut in interest rates from the Bank of England, the effects of which were exacerbated by the Federal Reserve’s move to raise US borrowing costs. Since the EU referendum, sterling has lost more than 17% of its value against the dollar and about 10% against the euro. The slump has been a mixed blessing for Britain’s leading companies, with some clear winners and losers. Winners Businesses which make most of their money overseas are the most obvious beneficiaries of sterling’s slide, since their earnings are now worth more when translated back into pounds. The luxury goods group Burberry, which generates about 85% of its sales abroad, has emerged as a clear winner, with overseas revenues bolstered even as its UK costs remain fixed. The icing on the cake is the weak pound attracting a growing number of overseas tourists, from China and elsewhere, to the UK keen to snap up its trademark checked scarves and camel trenchcoats. Burberry said this week the pound’s decline had lifted sales to tourists in its London stores by 30%. Its shares have jumped by about a third since referendum day, adding more than £1.5bn to its market capitalisation. Associated British Foods expects to benefit from the rising value of the euro against the pound. This will lift overseas profits, which last year made up half of the total, once they are translated back into sterling, and boost margins at ABF’s sugar business, although the group’s Primark fashion chain’s UK profit margins are taking a hit from the pound’s fall because clothes are largely bought in dollars. Mining groups listed on the London Stock Exchange but with operations everywhere from Australia to South America are also toasting the weak pound. Commodity prices are quoted in dollars, which lifts the value of the metals they mine in pound terms and boosts their profits. On top of that, precious metal miners such as Randgold Resources and Fresnillo have benefited from the recent strength of gold and silver, seen as havens in times of uncertainty. Other global businesses such as pharmaceuticals GlaxoSmithKline and AstraZeneca benefit from the exchange of overseas earnings into pounds, and are also supported by the relatively stable outlook for their businesses (threats by the US to clamp down on supposedly excessive prices notwithstanding.) Banks have had a more mixed time. Again overseas earners are to the fore, with HSBC, which makes around three quarters of its profits in Asia, and Barclays gaining ground. HSBC has had a hefty £37bn added to its stock market value since the referendum. Banks focused on the UK, such as Royal Bank of Scotland and Lloyds Banking Group have performed less well. Bookmakers have benefitted too, recording their biggest non-sporting event ever at the referendum, with punters placing £100m in bets. Most punters bet Britain would stay in the EU. Losers The companies most obviously hit by the falling pound are those most exposed to the UK economy, with the cost of imported goods rising just as demand seems set to weaken. If consumers are faced with having to pay more in the shops, they are likely to be more cautious with their spending. Supermarkets are facing increasing price pressures, as shown in the so-called Marmitegate dispute between Britain’s biggest grocer Tesco and consumer goods giant Unilever. Unilever raised prices on a range of products, from Marmite to Cif, by about 10% and halted deliveries to Tesco when the supermarket refused to accept the rises. This left Tesco short of several popular household brands. Although the dispute was resolved within days it is a sign of things to come in what is already a cut-throat and price-driven sector. Laith Khalaf, senior analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown, said: “Looking forward into 2017, the sector faces a new challenge from the rising cost of imported food, thanks to the fall in sterling, which will probably apply pressure to margins against such a competitive backdrop.” Staying on the high street, Sports Direct issued another profit warning in October – its third of the year – after it lost £15m in the currency markets as a result of the overnight “flash crash” in the value of sterling. Next estimated in August that its clothing prices would rise by up to 5% next year due to the pound’s decline. Its chief executive, Lord Wolfson, said the cost of buying goods from abroad in sterling had risen by 9% for next year’s fashions, although some of thehit would be offset by weakness in other currencies and its ability to squeeze better deals from suppliers. House prices are flat or falling as the weak pound dents consumer confidence and Brexit uncertainty pushes buyers out of deals. Housebuilders are facing weaker demand just as costs are rising. Bellway said some of its suppliers were likely to raise their prices due to the higher pound. Suppliers of imported timber have indicated that prices could rise by 10%. About 70% of Bellways’ materials are sourced from Britain, with 20% coming from Europe. “I’m sure we’re going to have what we would call some sort of Unilever moments with some of our suppliers,” the chief executive, Ted Ayres, told Reuters. Shares in the building sector have been under pressure since the referendum, with Britain’s biggest quoted housebuilder, Persimmon, losing 15% of its market value since the vote, equivalent to more than £1bn. Airlines are also suffering, as the falling pound makes travellers more reluctant to venture abroad and consumers decide to conserve their cash. Ryanair recently warned that full-year profits would be lower than expected, while EasyJet suffered its first fall in annual profits for six years due to the weak pound and discounting fares. EasyJet expects another drop in the current financial year. Currency movements cost the airline £88m as the pound’s decline against the dollar increased fuel costs.

webTitle: English sparkling wine industry toasts export record

fields.bodyText: The rise of English sparkling wine from a novelty to a major player in the global drinks market continues, with home-produced premium fizz now exported to a record 27 countries. Figures published by the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reveal the number of countries receiving cases of British bubbly, which makes up nearly 70% of the UK’s total wine production, was up from 19 in 2015, with exports heading to destinations such as Japan, Taiwan, France and Italy. “Thanks to sparkling rosé from Kent, and Chardonnay from Sussex, we are rightly taking our place among the world’s most renowned wine producers,” said the environment secretary, Andrea Leadsom. “The number of countries enjoying our wine has increased by a third this year, and with major producers on track to deliver a tenfold increase in exports, we could soon be tapping into more countries.” English wine producers have struggled in the past with an inconsistent climate and higher production costs than continental rivals. But now warmer temperatures and the UK’s chalky, south-facing slopes mean conditions are ideal for producing wine and ripe for a burgeoning industry that now boasts annual sales of around £100m a year. More than 5m bottles of wine – both sparkling and still – were produced in the UK in 2015. Growing demand has led to land under vine doubling over the last 10 years, with 30 vineyards opening in the last two years alone. There are more than 500 commercial vineyards in the UK comprising 133 wineries spread over approximately 5,000 acres of land. Among the lucrative new markets opened up this year was the US – with the first two full containers of English wine shipped to New York. In October, the Sussex-based Bolney Wine Estates announced a £2m investment to fund further production through a new winery and major expansion into the US, Scandinavia and Asia. In the UK, sales of homegrown wine at Marks & Spencer doubled while Waitrose sold 50% more English sparkling wine. Waitrose has added 12 new English sparkling wines, with sales up 49% compared with the same time last year – the biggest sales rise for any fizz. Cremant – a traditional method sparkling wine from the non-Champagne regions of France, enjoyed a sales increase of 27%, compared with 20% for Champagne, just ahead of Italian prosecco with 16% growth. Waitrose sparkling wine buyer Becky Hull said: “This year the nation’s appreciation of bubbles has continued to grow, with homegrown fizz proving to be the most popular. Whilst English sparkling has seen the most growth, sparkling wines in general have continued to thrive and with the festive season truly upon us, we think this New Year is set to be an extra bubbly one.”
